awd_titl_txt: RUI:   Completing Studies of Supernova Remnants and the Interstellar Medium
awd_abstract_narration:
Massive stars end their lives in catastrophic supernova explosions, releasing as much energy as the Sun will expend throughout its entire 10-billion-year lifetime.  Such an enormous energy release has profound effects on the galaxies where supernovae occur.  For example, the shock waves can trigger bursts of star formation when they encounter dense interstellar clouds.  Supernovae are also responsible for the production and distribution of most of the heavy elements in the Universe.  Virtually all elements from carbon to iron on the periodic table were forged in the cores of massive stars and distributed around the cosmos through supernova explosions.  The central themes of this research are to better understand (1) how supernovae explode, (2) how their huge energy release affects their host galaxies, and (3) how supernovae contribute to the chemical changes in the Universe.  The investigator and their students will focus on selected bright supernova remnants in the Milky Way.  Also, they will study the average effect of supernova remnants in the nearby galaxies.  The investigator is at Middlebury College, an ethnically diverse college in rural Vermont.  The investigator will work with undergraduate students and help them publish their research results.  The investigator will also reach out to the public via the striking images from the Emission Line Atlas to be published in popular literature and on the web.

This project will concentrate especially on young supernova remnants (SNRs), where observations made over three decades reveal significant expansion.  In young core-collapse SNRs, where uncontaminated ejecta fragments are freely expanding, image and spectroscopy data will be used to obtain proper motions and Doppler velocities for dozens of surviving ejecta knots to obtain 3-dimensional models and explore possible asymmetries.  Chemical abundances inferred from spectra can tie present knots to their origin in specific core layers of the progenitor stars.  In young Type Ia SNRs, specifically Tycho (SN1572) and RCW86 (SN185), proper motions of Balmer-dominated filaments that delineate their outer shells will be measured to gauge their expansion.  High signal-to-noise spectra of numerous filaments in both objects will enable determination of the shock velocities, which together with proper motions can yield the first precise distances to these key objects.  The investigator will also statistically investigate the properties of large SNR populations in an entire galaxy, where SNRs can be seen unimpeded by the foreground dust that hides from view most SNRs in the Milky Way.  The investigator and collaborators will identify the SNR populations in the two nearby galaxies which had the most supernovae in the past century.

por.por_cntn:
Supernovae are the cataclysmic events in which massive stars end their lives.  The immense energy they release, as much as the Sun will radiate over its entire 10-billion-year lifetime, has profound effects on the dynamics of their host galaxy and can trigger episodes of star formation.  Supernovae are responsible for producing most of the heavy elements in the Universe--those from carbon to iron on the periodic table.  This project has been directed toward better understanding supernovae and the galaxies in which they occur, primarily through the study of supernova remnants.

 One aspect of our work has been to explore supernovae in our own galaxy, in particular "Type Ia" events, believed to occur when a highly collapsed white dwarf star in a binary system accretes so much matter from its companion that it catastrophically collapses further into a neutron star, accompanied by the release of an immense amount of gravitational energy.  We published several papers along this theme:

 Perhaps most important concerns the most recent supernova (SN) to be seen in our galaxy occurred in 1572 CE, and is associated with the great Danish astronomer Tycho Brahe, who recorded detailed records of his observations.  This "Tycho’s SN" has been conclusively shown to have been a Type Ia event.  Considerable effort over the past few decades has gone into searching for a binary companion that would have remained after the explosion, and one star, "Tycho B," has emerged as the most likely candidate.  Type Ia SNe are known to release a large amount if iron, and if Tycho B is the long-lost companion, we would expect to see definite signatures of iron in its spectrum.  But our observations with the STIS instrument on the Hubble Space Telescope showed no trace of iron; furthermore, Tycho B appears to be considerably closer than the 1572 SN.  Thus, it seems that Tycho B is most likely a foreground interloper.  The search for a runaway companion for SN1572 continues.  (Kerzendorf et al. 2018, MNRAS, 479, 5696).

 The greatest share of our effort has gone into surveys of nearby galaxies—ones closer than about 25 million light years—to identify supernova remnants (SNRs) and study their properties.  My collaborators and I have carried out studies of several galaxies: M33, a spiral galaxy somewhat smaller than the Milky Way where we used spectroscopy of almost 200 SNRs to show that this galaxy has relatively low abundances of heavy elements.  We have also carried out searches for SNRs in the rich spiral galaxies M83 (the southern pinwheel), ("High-resolution Spectra of Supernova Remnants in M83," Winkler, P. Frank, Long, Knox S., Blair, William P., and Points, Sean D., The Astrophysical Journal, 943:15), NGC6946, the "fireworks galaxy" ,which has produced more SNe (10) than any other galaxy, and M51, and have identified hundreds of SNRs.  M51, in particular seems to an have especially high abundance of heavy elements, especially nitrogen.

 Perhaps our most important contribution is a study of the brightest SNRs in the Large Magellanic Cloud, nearest neighbor galaxy to the Milky Way.  There we showed the utility of a new criterion for determining that nebulae are SNRs: the velocity broadening of their spectral lines.  This provides an important supplement to the commonly-used [S II]:Ha line strength ratio.  "Kinematics: A Clean Diagnostic for Separating Supernova Remnants from H II Regions in Nearby Galaxies,"  Points, S.D., Long, K.S., Winkler, P.F., & Blair, W.P. 2019, The Astrophysical Journal, 887:66.  We followed this with a high-resolution study of M83 ("High-resolution Spectra of Supernova Remnants in M83," Winkler, P. Frank, Long, Knox S., Blair, William P., and Points, Sean D., The Astrophysical Journal, 943:15) and finally with a study of SNRs in the prominent irregular galaxy NGC4449 ("Supernova Remnants in the Irregular Galaxy NGC 4449" P. Frank Winkler, Knox S. Long, and William P. Blair, The Astrophysical Journal, in press).  In all these cases, most of the SNRs have lines that are at least somewhat broader than those for other nebulae.

 In addition to the scientific accomplishments, the PI served as mentor to a Middlebury College undergraduate, Sadie Coffin in the summer of 2019.  They worked closely together on the survey of the M51 galaxy (above) during that summer and well after.  Sadie presented a paper at the American Astronomical Society meeting in Honolulu in January, 2020 and co-authored our paper for the Astrophysical Journal.  She became much inspired by this research, and is now pursuing a PhD program at the University of Rochester.

 Finally, PI Winkler helped to facilitate and run several "open-house nights" at Middlebury College’s Mittelman Observatory.  These popular events typically draw several hundred visitors from the local area and well beyond.  Unfortunately, the pandemic curtailed them severely in the summers of 2020 and 2021.
